item.title: Farming activities
item.description: Status: 🌱 Farming activities Weeding Weeds can be dangerous for young plants as they can compete for soil nutrient and for sunlight.

item.title: Japanese Standard cup sizes
item.description: Status: 🌱 Japanese Standard cup sizes [[Sencha 煎茶]] also know as sencha-wan, 80-120ml round shape white coloured porcelain. [[Gyokuro 玉露茶]] also know as Gyokurocha-wan, ~30ml round shape white coloured porcelain.

item.title: Steamed vs pan-fired teas
item.description: Status: 🌱 Steamed vs pan-fired teas [[Steamed processed teas 蒸し製]] teas have a stronger release of flavour at the beginning. While [[Pan-fired teas 釜炒り茶]] develop more during the later brews.

item.title: Yuzamashi 湯冷し
item.description: Status: 🌱 Yuzamashi 湯冷し Water cooler, used to help cool down water for high grade teas. Paired usually to a [[Shiboridashi 絞り出し]] or a [[Kyusu 急須]].

item.title: Enshu School
item.description: Status: 🌱 Enshu School https://www.enshuryu.com/enshuryu/ References Tags: Type: #idea Zettelkasten UID: 202212212106

item.title: Kyoto-Uji 京都・宇治
item.description: Status: 🌱 Kyoto-Uji 京都・宇治 Includes regions like: Uji Ujitawara Wazuka Yamashiro Uji used to be the main producer, now it has grown into a modern city, so the production has moved out to the surrounding areas.

item.title: Shiboridashi 絞り出し
item.description: Status: 🌱 Shiboridashi 絞り出し Derived from [[Gaiwan]], it also has a simpler spout and filter than [[Houin]]. Often paired with a [[Yuzamashi 湯冷し]]

item.title: Tea evaluation
item.description: Status: 🌱 Tea evaluation There are two main types: Auction: Usually thematic by day(Sencha, Tencha, Gyokuro…) Competition: Like in hand rolled competitions f.

item.title: Mie 三重
item.description: Status: 🌱 Mie 三重 includes regions like: Yokkaichi Suzuka Kameyama Linan Watarai Presents more of the production in the northern area, where there are more flatlands as well.

item.title: Miyazaki 宮崎
item.description: Status: 🌱 Miyazaki 宮崎 includes regions like: Takachiho Gokase Kawaminami Miyakonojo Kushima Although it is neibourh with [[Kagoshima 鹿児島]] the spread of the farms is quite diferent.

item.title: Fukamushi 深蒸し
item.description: Status: 🌱 Fukamushi 深蒸し Deep steamed [[Steamed processed teas 蒸し製]] variant of [[Sencha 煎茶]], for young or coarser leafs as well.

item.title: Japanese Black Tea 和紅茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Japanese Black Tea 和紅茶 Black tea, mostly experimental at this point, but with a new push for developing it due to the drop in price for green tea over the last years.

item.title: Japanese Oolong ウーロン茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Japanese Oolong ウーロン茶 100-150 years the production started with somewhat of a success although it stopped being produced for many year in noticeable amounts.

item.title: Kabusecha 被せ煎茶・被せ茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Kabusecha 被せ煎茶・被せ茶 High grade loose-leaf tea, made with buds and young leafs. Sahded around 2 weeks with spring and summer harvest.

item.title: Konacha 粉茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Konacha 粉茶 Japanese tea fanning, y-product of high-grade teas like [[Gyokuro 玉露茶]], [[Kabusecha 被せ煎茶・被せ茶]] and [[Sencha 煎茶]] most commonly.

item.title: Kukicha 茎茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Kukicha 茎茶 By-product tea separated out from [[Matcha 抹茶]], [[Gyokuro 玉露茶]], [[Kabusecha 被せ煎茶・被せ茶]], [[Sencha 煎茶]] etc in spring and summer.

item.title: Okumidori おくみどり
item.description: Status: 🌱 Okumidori おくみどり 3% of used cultivars. [[Shizuoka 静岡]] 1974. One of the cultivars with more [[Umami]]. Late shooter, good yield, used for [[Gyokuro 玉露茶]] and [[Tencha 挽き茶・碾茶]]

item.title: Saemidori さえみどり
item.description: Status: 🌱 Saemidori さえみどり [[Kagoshima 鹿児島]] 1990, presents more [[Umami]], early shooting, good yield. Very promising cultivar, also good for [[Shaded teas 覆下栽培]].

item.title: Sayamakaori さやまかおり
item.description: Status: 🌱 Sayamakaori さやまかおり 2% of used cultivars. [[Saitama 埼玉]] 1971. Bit astringent, strong aromas, good yield, resistant to cold, used for [[Sencha 煎茶]].

item.title: Yutakamidori ゆたかみどり
item.description: Status: 🌱 Yutakamidori ゆたかみどり Represents 7% of the cultivars used as of 2020, registered in [[Shizuoka 静岡]] in 1966. Early shooter, good yield, more astringent, weak against cold.

item.title: Zairai 在来種
item.description: Status: 🌱 Zairai 在来種 around 1% of used genetic plant material. Natural mix of plants, unpredictable shooting, resistance to cold and insects.

item.title: Kagoshima 鹿児島
item.description: Status: 🌱 Kagoshima 鹿児島 Includes regions like: Chiran Ei Kirishima Oura Takabe Ariake Tanegashima Yakushima Tea is grown all around the sea line with very few mountain sides having operations as the mountains in the Kagoshima area can be very high altitude of 1700 meters in some areas.

item.title: Shizuoka 静岡
item.description: Status: 🌱 Shizuoka 静岡 includes regions like: Fuji Honyama Shimizu Kawane Tenryu Kakegawa Makinohara Ashikubo On the sea line the land is flatter and the land is developed into large scale production.

item.title: Japan Tea Distribution
item.description: Status: 🌱 Japan Tea Distribution The three main actors are the growers, processors and the distributors. Although not every region has the same structures we can identify three main routes of distribution.

item.title: Camellia Sinensis
item.description: Status: 🌱 Camellia Sinensis Camellia are plants from the Theaceae family and it is a genus of flowering plant found in eastern and southeastern Asia.

item.title: Sencha vs Gyokuro
item.description: Status: 🌱 Sencha vs Gyokuro Perhaps the most noticeable difference between [[Sencha 煎茶]] and [[Gyokuro 玉露茶]] are the shading as the [[Processing method 製茶方法]] can be quite similar at first glance.

item.title: Yabukita やぶきた
item.description: Status: 🌱 Yabukita やぶきた Was the first cultivar to be bred in [[Shizuoka 静岡]] in 1908, although it was not registered after some time later in 1953.

item.title: Benihomare
item.description: Status: 🌱 Benihomare original black tea [[Japanese Black Tea 和紅茶]]cultivar brought from Himalayas by —-, an envoy of the shogun at the time sent with silk and green tea.

item.title: Baisao
item.description: Status: 🌱 Baisao Was a monk living in the Edo period (1603 - 1868) between the 1675 and 1763 when he passed away un the city of Kyoto.

item.title: Bancha 番茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Bancha 番茶 Lower grade, mature leaves. Grown under sun, summer* harvest or considered as the second part of the spring harvest

item.title: Brewing factors
item.description: Status: 🌱 Brewing factors Type of tea Temperature Part of the leave used Water type Tea quality Time Tea:water ratio Water quality Hard water clouds and masks the tea flavour.

item.title: Caffeine
item.description: Status: 🌱 Caffeine Belongs to Methylxanthine group, is another of the compounds that form part of the defence plant system. Used to be known as Teina because they were thought to be different compounds.

item.title: Catechin
item.description: Status: 🌱 Catechin Catechin Belongs to the polyphenol group, and it is part of the defence system of the plant. Used to be known as Tannin.

item.title: Genmaicha 玄米茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Genmaicha 玄米茶 Genmaicha is a [[Reprocessed teas 再加工茶]]variation of green tea that is mixed with roasted rice. The base tea leaf is usually [[Bancha 番茶]] but some can be found with [[Sencha 煎茶]] as well.

item.title: Hojicha ほうじ茶・焙じ茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Hojicha ほうじ茶・焙じ茶 Lower grade tea, usually made from [[Bancha 番茶]] that has been roasted. References [[100 Foundation Course MOC]]

item.title: L-Theanine
item.description: Status: 🌱 L-Theanine Theanine Also known as L-Theanine belongs to the amino acids family, can be found in Tea and some mushroom families.

item.title: Storage of tea
item.description: Status: 🌱 Storage of tea When storing tea the most important things to consider are: Air Temperature Light Moisture Smells The affect [[L-Theanine]], [[Caffeine]], [[Catechin]], Vitamins and Chlorophyll.

item.title: Vitamin C
item.description: Status: 🌱 Vitamin C The name is Ascorbic Acid, present in citrus, many other fruits and vegetables. Has some tart, sour taste but not to much quantity is found in tea so it is not as noticeable usually.

item.title: 100 History of the Japanese Tea
item.description: Status: 🌱 History of the Japanese Tea Following is what we know from Tea in Japan, how it arrived, was grown and drink, and eventually diverged from the Chinese Tea Culture onto it own.

item.title: Temperature and Infusion time relation
item.description: Status: 🌱 Temperature and Infusion time relation Different temperatures solubilise different compounds, like caffeine for example. The time will in part allow more of them to be diffused into the brew.

item.title: Temperature and Infusion time relation
item.description: Status: 🌱 Temperature and Infusion time relation Different temperatures solubilise different compounds, like caffeine for example. The time will in part allow more of them to be diffused into the brew.

item.title: Temperature and Infusion time relation
item.description: Status: 🌱 Temperature and Infusion time relation Different temperatures solubilise different compounds, like caffeine for example. The time will in part allow more of them to be diffused into the brew.

item.title: Aromatic compounds
item.description: Status: 🌱 Aromatic compounds There are more than 300 volatile compounds found in tea. Most of the compound’s effects, characteristics, and interaction with one another are not known.

item.title: Brew color 水色
item.description: Status: 🌱 The brew of the tea is one of the key factors in determining the quality of the tea itself.

item.title: Green colour preservation
item.description: Status: 🌱 Chlorophyll is the main reason for the green color in plants. When the leaves are picked and left as it is the oxidation process will shift the color from green to a brownish black color.

item.title: Harvesting method 収穫方法
item.description: Status: 🌱 収穫 しゅうかく Tea can be harvested by hand 手摘み (てづみ) or by machine 機械摘み (きかいづみ). Hand harvesting 手摘み Until the Taisho Era (1912–26) manual hand harvesting was the main method.

item.title: Processing method 製茶方法
item.description: Status: 🌱 After harvesting the leaf material it is transported into the factories, were it undergoes it’s transformation into a product that can be brewed later.

item.title: cultivar 品種
item.description: Status: 🌱 Every varietal cultivar affects the following: 品種特製 ・Taste 味 ・Smell 香り ・amount and time of harvest 収穫量と収穫時期 Diseases and cold resistance 病気・病気・寒さへの抵抗性 [[Yabukita やぶきた]] is the most cultivated one currently at 70%, the second one is [[Yutakamidori ゆたかみどり]]] at 6%.

item.title: Cultivation methods 栽培方法
item.description: Status: 🌱 Includes compost management, triming, organic cultivation methods, etc One of the more important ones and key to the [[Shaded teas 覆下栽培]] like [[Tencha 挽き茶・碾茶]] and [[Gyokuro 玉露茶]] cultivation is the [[Japanese tea shading techniques]].

item.title: Shaded teas 覆下栽培
item.description: Status: 🌱 覆下栽培 Is the method of growing tea under shades to improve the flavour of the leafs using the [[Japanese tea shading techniques]].

item.title: Matcha 抹茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Matcha is the traditional powder tea made from [[Tencha 挽き茶・碾茶]] References [[The Story of Japanese Tea]] [[Japanese Tea - A comprehensive guide]]

item.title: Tencha 挽き茶・碾茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 Tencha is the leaf used to produce [[Matcha 抹茶]], a powdered tea made from ground tea leafs, traditionally in a stone mill.

item.title: Japanese tea shading techniques
item.description: Status: 🌱 See also: [[Shaded teas 覆下栽培]] Japanese tea shading techniques 被覆方法 Sweetness is one of the main desired flavours together with [[Umami]].

item.title: Gyokuro 玉露茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 玉露茶 translated as “Jade Dew” is one of the [[Shaded teas 覆下栽培]], together with [[Tencha 挽き茶・碾茶]], and the Shaded version of [[Sencha 煎茶]], [[Kabusecha 被せ煎茶・被せ茶]].

item.title: Steamed teas
item.description: Status: 🌱 Before 1738 the production of tea was mainly [[Tencha 挽き茶・碾茶]]. Which is a steamed and dried tea for matcha production.

item.title: Sencha 煎茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 煎茶 is the most common tea produce in Japan. It is generally an unshaded tea, but it can be shaded as well, known as [[Kabusecha 被せ煎茶・被せ茶]].

item.title: Kamairicha 釜炒り茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 釜炒り茶 (Kamairicha) is composed of Kama (釜), (iron pot, pan, cauldron) and 炒り (fry, roast, parch). Also, can be seen labelled as Kamaguri 釜ぐり.

item.title: Tamaryokucha 玉緑茶
item.description: Status: 🌱 More regional variation found in Kyushu mainly. Tamaryokucha 玉緑茶 means ball or curly green tea. Includes two tea manufacturing process dependent on if Steam 蒸し製玉緑茶 or pan-firing was used, 釜炒り製玉緑茶.

item.title: Tsuyu Hikari 梅雨光
item.description: Status: 🌱 Varietal resistant to pest. Original from [[Shizuoka 静岡]] and low in availability, only sold in the prefecture for now.

item.title: Comodity Tea & Specialty Tea
item.description: Status: 🌱 Commodity is bulk tea actively traded and the price is determined by the markets. The price is usually in currency/Kg.
